articles.headline: A Literary Legend Fights for a Local Library
articles.snippet: The new passion of the science fiction writer Ray Bradbury is raising money for California’s libraries.
articles.abstract: The new passion of the science fiction writer Ray Bradbury is raising money for California’s libraries.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENTURA, Calif.  When you are pushing 90, have written scores of famous novels, short stories and screenplays, and have fulfilled the goal of taking a simulated ride to Mars, what’s left?

articles.headline: Soft Market for Cashmere Takes Toll in China
articles.snippet: As Western demand for luxury sweaters erodes, goat farms in Inner Mongolia are feeling the impact.
articles.abstract: As Western demand for luxury sweaters erodes, goat farms in Inner Mongolia are feeling the impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOHHOT, China  This summer, as always, the cashmere on offer in department stores and malls is mostly in ultrathin “summer weight” tops. Come fall, these usually are replaced by thick, luxuriant sweaters. But this year is shaping up to be different.

articles.headline: Tables Turn in Porsche’s Pursuit of VW
articles.snippet: Years of family intrigue factored into the drama when Porsche shifted from Volkwagen’s predator to its prey.
articles.abstract: Years of family intrigue factored into the drama when Porsche shifted from Volkwagen’s predator to its prey.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  When Wolfgang Porsche learned that his family’s sports car company would need an emergency cash infusion from its giant rival Volkswagen, he “went absolutely white.”

articles.headline: Hard Times for New England’s 3-Deckers
articles.snippet: Three-decker homes, a regional emblem in New England, are being foreclosed on at disproportionate rates, left to decay and even razed.
articles.abstract: Three-decker homes, a regional emblem in New England, are being foreclosed on at disproportionate rates, left to decay and even razed.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BEDFORD, Mass.  As foreclosures batter the dense neighborhoods of urban New England, a regional emblem is under siege.

articles.headline: In Recession, Strategy Shifts for Big Chains
articles.snippet: Retailers’ reinvention includes regionalization of merchandise and midpriced items at high-end stores.
articles.abstract: Retailers’ reinvention includes regionalization of merchandise and midpriced items at high-end stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shopping as we know it is on the brink of major change.

articles.headline: Unlikely Partners in a Cause
articles.snippet: The move to regulation of tobacco by the Food and Drug Administration has happened in part because of the effort of a former cigarette executive.
articles.abstract: The move to regulation of tobacco by the Food and Drug Administration has happened in part because of the effort of a former cigarette executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last week, just after the Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill to give the Food and Drug Administration regulatory authority over the deadliest legal product known to man  cigarettes  Steven C. Parrish sent an e-mail message to David A. Kessler.

articles.headline: Obama Resists Calls for a Tougher Stance on Iran
articles.snippet: President Obama’s reluctance to respond more forcefully may change if Tehran carries out a sweeping crackdown.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s reluctance to respond more forcefully may change if Tehran carries out a sweeping crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With Iran on a razor’s edge after a week of swelling protests, the Obama administration has fended off pressure from both parties to respond more forcefully to the disputed election there. But if Iranian authorities carry out their latest threat of a more sweeping crackdown, the White House would reconsider its carefully calibrated tone, officials said Friday.

articles.headline: For Older Investors, Old Rules May Not Apply
articles.snippet: The fall in the stock market has analysts giving conflicting advice to investors with short time windows.
articles.abstract: The fall in the stock market has analysts giving conflicting advice to investors with short time windows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market’s damage has already been done. And if you’re one of those people near or already in retirement, you already know you’re going to have to work longer, save more or spend less.

articles.headline: Violence Grips Tehran Amid Crackdown
articles.snippet: As police officers used sticks and tear gas to disperse thousands of demonstrators, the opposition leader, Mir Hussein Moussavi, said at a rally that “I am ready for martyrdom.”
articles.abstract: As police officers used sticks and tear gas to disperse thousands of demonstrators, the opposition leader, Mir Hussein Moussavi, said at a rally that “I am ready for martyrdom.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Police officers used sticks and tear gas to force back thousands of demonstrators under plumes of black smoke in the capital on Saturday, a day after Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said there would be “bloodshed” if street protests continued over the disputed presidential election.

articles.headline: Too Big to Fail, or Too Big to Handle?
articles.snippet: The Treasury’s plan for stronger oversight may not eliminate a need for more and costlier bailouts.
articles.abstract: The Treasury’s plan for stronger oversight may not eliminate a need for more and costlier bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: “No one should assume that the government will step in to bail them out if their firm fails.”

articles.headline: Times Reporter Escapes Taliban After 7 Months
articles.snippet: David Rohde, a New York Times reporter kidnapped by the Taliban, made his way to freedom Friday night.
articles.abstract: David Rohde, a New York Times reporter kidnapped by the Taliban, made his way to freedom Friday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Rohde, a New York Times reporter who was kidnapped by the Taliban, escaped Friday night and made his way to freedom after more than seven months of captivity in the mountains of Afghanistan and Pakistan.

articles.headline: Treasury’s Got Bill Gross on Speed Dial
articles.snippet: With the collapse of Wall Street, Bill Gross of Pimco has emerged as one of the nation’s most influential financiers.
articles.abstract: With the collapse of Wall Street, Bill Gross of Pimco has emerged as one of the nation’s most influential financiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newport Beach, Calif.

articles.headline: Unrest in Iran Sharply Deepens Rift Among Clerics
articles.snippet: The government linked the opposition leader to “terrorist” elements for the first time and briefly arrested relatives of his powerful backer, a founder of the Islamic republic.
articles.abstract: The government linked the opposition leader to “terrorist” elements for the first time and briefly arrested relatives of his powerful backer, a founder of the Islamic republic.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  A bitter rift among Iran’s ruling clerics deepened Sunday over the disputed presidential election that has convulsed Tehran in the worst violence in 30 years, with the government trying to link the defiant loser to terrorists and detaining relatives of his powerful backer, a founder of the Islamic republic.
articles.byline: By Nazila Fathi and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Small Carmakers Benefit From Detroit’s Woes
articles.snippet: Many smaller automakers are gaining a bigger share of the American market, most notably Hyundai and Kia.
articles.abstract: Many smaller automakers are gaining a bigger share of the American market, most notably Hyundai and Kia.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  As if Detroit didn’t have enough worries.

articles.headline: Investors Bet on Payments via Cellphone
articles.snippet: Investors are trying to turn phones into virtual credit cards, enabling click-and-buy commerce.
articles.abstract: Investors are trying to turn phones into virtual credit cards, enabling click-and-buy commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  On a PC, having to fill out a form and type in a credit card number to buy something is only mildly annoying. On a cellphone, it could make you want to skip the purchase entirely.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: How Good (or Not Evil) Is Google?
articles.snippet: After Google scanned millions of books without permission, some wonder how the behemoth can avoid making tsunamis instead of waves.
articles.abstract: After Google scanned millions of books without permission, some wonder how the behemoth can avoid making tsunamis instead of waves.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

articles.headline: Paramount Bets Its Summer Largely on One Producer
articles.snippet: Studios have trimmed their release schedules and cut back on exclusive deals with producers, bolstering the position of a few gatekeepers.
articles.abstract: Studios have trimmed their release schedules and cut back on exclusive deals with producers, bolstering the position of a few gatekeepers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  On Tuesday, Lorenzo di Bonaventura was in Moscow. Before that, it was Amsterdam, then Rome. And by Friday, he was back here, to prep for a Westwood film premiere, even as management at his home base, Paramount Pictures, was in disarray again.

articles.headline: With a Plan and a Rope, Captives Escaped Taliban
articles.snippet: An Afghan journalist who was held by the Taliban along with a Times reporter revealed the details of their escape.
articles.abstract: An Afghan journalist who was held by the Taliban along with a Times reporter revealed the details of their escape.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  An Afghan journalist who was held captive by the Taliban for more than seven months along with a New York Times reporter revealed details on Sunday of a nighttime escape that included weeks of careful plotting, taking advantage of weary guards and dropping down a 20-foot wall with a rope.

articles.headline: As The Boston Globe Struggled, Confusion Prevailed
articles.snippet: A lack of communication between a union and its members has typified one of the most contentious newspaper labor fights in years.
articles.abstract: A lack of communication between a union and its members has typified one of the most contentious newspaper labor fights in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost exactly a year ago, on June 23, more than 200 employees at The Boston Globe packed into the newspaper’s ground-floor auditorium to hear what visiting executives from The New York Times Company had to say. One worker asked about a company proposal to cut salaries 10 percent.

articles.headline: U.S. Tightens Airstrike Policy in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: New restrictions announced by the U.S. commander in Afghanistan are part of an effort to reduce civilian deaths.
articles.abstract: New restrictions announced by the U.S. commander in Afghanistan are part of an effort to reduce civilian deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The new American commander in Afghanistan said he would sharply restrict the use of airstrikes here, in an effort to reduce the civilian deaths that he said were undermining the American-led mission.

articles.headline: Judge’s Mentor: Part Guide, Part Foil
articles.snippet: Sonia Sotomayor has had a long association with José A. Cabranes, first as protégé and mentor, then as often-opposing judges.
articles.abstract: Sonia Sotomayor has had a long association with José A. Cabranes, first as protégé and mentor, then as often-opposing judges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Not long after her admission to Yale Law School in early 1976, Sonia Sotomayor turned up unexpectedly at a lunch with the university’s general counsel, José A. Cabranes.

articles.headline: Mind Your BlackBerry or Mind Your Manners
articles.snippet: As Web-enabled smartphones have become standard, the etiquette of using them during meetings is up for debate.
articles.abstract: As Web-enabled smartphones have become standard, the etiquette of using them during meetings is up for debate.

articles.headline: States Turning to Last Resorts in Budget Crisis
articles.snippet: With revenues in a free fall, governors and legislatures are approving measures that were once unthinkable.
articles.abstract: With revenues in a free fall, governors and legislatures are approving measures that were once unthinkable.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Hawaii, state employees are bracing for furloughs of three days a month over the next two years, the equivalent of a 14 percent pay cut. In Idaho, lawmakers reduced aid to public schools for the first time in recent memory, forcing pay cuts for teachers.

articles.headline: Amid Crackdown, Iran Admits Voting Errors
articles.snippet: The police broke up a group of about a thousand protesters in Tehran as officials acknowledged voting discrepancies in at least 50 cities.
articles.abstract: The police broke up a group of about a thousand protesters in Tehran as officials acknowledged voting discrepancies in at least 50 cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Iran’s most powerful oversight council announced on Monday that the number of votes recorded in 50 cities exceeded the number of eligible voters there by three million, further tarnishing a presidential election that has set off the most sustained challenge to Iran’s leadership in 30 years.

articles.headline: Justices Retain Oversight by U.S. on Voting
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court said that there was no need at the moment to address the constitutionality of the provision in light of changes that have swept the South.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court said that there was no need at the moment to address the constitutionality of the provision in light of changes that have swept the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday left intact one of the signature legacies of the civil rights movement, the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
